send something/somebody ↔ in.translation: to send something, usually by post, to a place where it can be dealt with
I sent in a few job applications last week.
to send soldiers, police etc somewhere to deal with a difficult or dangerous situation
British troops were sent in as part of the peace-keeping force.
to send something, usually by mail, to a place where it can be dealt with
Customers can send in their sales receipts to get the discount coupons.
to tell someone to go somewhere to do a particular task, especially a difficult one
The DTI may send in inspectors who will, if necessary, stop the company trading.
